newsitem.title: NORWAY: Sea Launch delays first satellite launch.
newsitem.headline: Sea Launch delays first satellite launch.

text.p: Sea Launch Co. has delayed the launch of the first satellite from a sea platform until October, 1998, four months behind schedule, a company spokesman said on Tuesday.
The 350 million stg project -- backed by firms from the U.S., Russia, Norway and Ukraine -- originally planned its first launch in June next year.
"It is correct that the schedule for the first launch is now in October 1998. It was meant to be in the summer," said Hans Petter Hoegh, CFO at Sea Launch in Oslo.

"It is a complex project, the first of its kind, and we want to get it right. There are several different elements to our decision," Hoegh told Reuters. He declined to elaborate on the different factors.

Investors in Sea Launch are Boeing Co.'s Commercial Space division with 40 percent, RSC-Energia of Russia with 25 percent, Anglo-Norwegian construction and engineering group Kvaerner with 20 percent and NPO-Yuzhnoye of Ukraine holding 15 percent.
Sea Launch will use the converted oil rig, Odyssey, to fire Russian-made Zenits rockets from a position in the Pacific Ocean. The rockets will be transported and assembled on the control ship.
